intro: Atrategia thomsonii, commonly known as Thomson's ice plant, is a succulent species native to the cold, alpine regions of South America. It is characterized by its fleshy, blue-green leaves that store water, allowing it to survive in arid and frost-prone environments. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers during the summer months, which attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained soils and requires full sun exposure to flourish. Due to its unique adaptations, it is often cultivated in rock gardens and alpine settings where it can mimic its natural habitat.
